div.p: The Mean Field Theory in EM Procedures for Blind Markov Random Field Image Restoration

div.head: Jun Zhang
div.p: Abstract-A Markov random field (MRF) model-based EM (expectation-maximization) procedure for simultaneously estimating the degradation model and restoring the image is described. The MRF is a coupled one which provides continuity (inside regions of smooth gray tones) and discontinuity (at region boundaries) constraints for the restoration problem which is, in general, ill-posed. The computational difficulty associated with the EM procedure for MRF's is resolved by using the mean field theory from statistical mechanics. An orthonormal blur decomposition is used to reduce the chances of undesirable locally optimal estimates. Experimental results on synthetic and real-world images show that this approach provides good blur estimates and restored images. The restored images are comparable to those obtained by a Wiener filter in mean-square error, but are more visually pleasing.

div.head: INTRODUCTION
div.p: MAG€ restoration is an important and difficult problem in I image processing applications [1] (for a recent review, see [2]). The difficulty is mainly due to two factors. First, image restoration is often an ill-posed inverse problem, where the inverse does not exist or is unstable. Second, the degradation process is often unknown and has to be estimated from observed data. The problem of simultaneously estimating the degradation model and restoring the image is known as blind image restoration.

The inverse problem has been attacked by using various Wiener filters [I], Kalman filters [3], and more recently, MRF model-based Bayesian techniques [4]- [SI and regularization [6]. The idea here is to bring as many constraints as possible to bear to obtain a unique and robust inverse. The MRF model-based techniques have attracted much attention due to their generality for modeling and their capacity to incorporate various constraints. They can be used to account for casual and noncasual image models [7], smooth regions and boundaries in the image. linear and nonlinear blurs, and various types of noise [4]. Furthermore, the MRF models fit naturally in a Bayesian [maximum a posferiori probability (MAP)] formulation of the image restoration problem. Finally, it was pointed out in [SI that the standard regularization techniques Manuscript received February 19. 1992: revised August 18, 1992. The degradation model estimation problem was previously attacked by blind deconvolution [9], and recently by maximum-likelihood estimation [ 101 and the EM algorithm [ 1 11-[ 121. Blind deconvolution techniques often require that the type of blur (e.g., motion blur, etc.) be known, and hence are somewhat restrictive. The EM algorithm, on the other hand, is a maximum-likelihood (ML) parameter estimation procedure for incomplete data, and it does not, in principle, restrict the type of blur. Through an iterative process, it provides not only an estimate of the blur, but also a restoration of the image. Hence, it attracted much attention recently as a more general approach to blind image restoration.

Previously, some promising image restoration results have been obtained by using the coupled MRF model with known blur models [4]-[S], and by using the EM algorithm without MRF modeling [7]. [ I I]. Hence, an MRF-based EM algorithm may provide a powerful technique for blind image restoration. However, the difficulty here is that when the original image is modeled as an MRF, the conditional expectation in the EM algorithm is difficult to calculate. In recent work [13], we have proposed a solution based on the mean field theory, and demonstrated its efficacy for unsupervised image segmentation where the MRF is discrete-valued. In this work, we extend this approach to the image restoration problem where the MRF is coupled and continuous-valued. As a byproduct, we will also develop a scheme for calculating mean fields with relatively complex clique structures. The mean field theory has its origin in statistical mechanics (e.g., [ 14]), and was recently used in computer vision applications [ 15]- [17]. Zerubia and Chellappa [16], Hiriyannaiah et al. [32], and Bilbro and Snyder [33] have used this method for noise removal.

There are several common implementation problems facing most EM-algorithm-based techniques for image restoration, as described by Lagendijk et al. [l 11. For example, the blur model often has a large number of parameters to be estimated, and this makes it easy for the EM procedure to get "struck" in an unwanted local optimum. Furthermore, blur model estimation may itself be an ill-posed problem. In this work, we have studied a blur model decomposition scheme and a smoothness constraint for solving these problems.

div.head: IV. IMPLEMENTATION
div.p: In this section, we first discuss some ideas for attacking the common technical problems associated with blur parameter estimation described in Section I, and then describe the implementation of the E-step and the M-step in some detail.

div.head: A . Blur Decomposition
div.p: In many practical applications, the blur process can be effectively modeled by an FIR filter, as is in ( 14). However, this might cause problems in the AT-step [ l l ] . For example, there might be too many parameters to estimate, even for a blur model for moderate size (e.g., a 5 x 5 filter has 25 coefficients to be estimated), thereby increasing the chances for the M-step to get stuck in an unwanted local maximum [ l l ] . Although various symmetry conditions have been imposed previously to reduce the number of coefficients, it might still be too large if the size of the blur filter is relatively large (e.g., 9 x 9).

In this work, we propose an alternative approach inspired by transform image compression techniques (e.g., see [25]). If we regard a 2-D blur filter as an "image," this image is usually very "smooth." Hence, it may be compressed by using a small number of transform coefficients, thereby reducing the number of parameters to be estimated. Another potential advantage of this approach is that each transform coefficient, unlike the original blur filter coefficients, captures some "global" feature of the blur, and the estimates might be more robust.
Mathematically, the transform technique is simply a decomposition of the blur filter with respect to a prespecified basis.

Let F D be the space of all of the real functions defined on D , the region of support for b. Then, where the (->k's are the basis functions and the r k ' s are the coefficients. div.head: V. EXPERIMENTAL RESULTS
div.p: Image restoration experiments were performed on both synthetic and real-world images. Synthetic images were used first to ensure correct implementation and to study the effect of various control parameters.

div.head: A. Sytithetic ImagcJs

The original image is a 20 x 20 array whose first and second ten rows are -1 and +1, respectively, as shown in Fig. 5(a). This synthetic image is then blurred by a 5 x 5 uniform blur [see Table III (b)]. Realizations of zero-mean white Gaussian noise with variances of 0.0001 and 0.01, respectively, are added to the blurred image to generate two test images, referred to as T1 and T2 and shown in Figs. S(b) and 6(b), respectively. The signal-tonoise ratios (SNR's)' for these two test images are then about 40 and 20 dB, respectively (since the power of the original image is 1).

In both cases, the true blur parameters and noise variances are used. When the true blur parameters are used, the only difference between one Estep of our EM procedure and Jeng and Woods' program is that the former uses the mean field theory, while the latter uses simulated annealing. The Lena image seems more difficult to restore than the synthetic images in Section V-A, which is, of course, not surprising. We also found it helpful to use a small A0 for blur parameter estimation, and then a larger AO for the final restoration.

The following observations can be made from the restoration results. First, when the blur parameters are known, the mean field theory approach provides restorations that are comparable to that of Jeng and Woods' program [5] with less computation time (the E-step converges within ten update cycles or about SO min of CPU time on a Convex). Second, when the blur parameters are not known, the EM procedure provides good parameter estimates, and the restoration results are close to those obtained with known blur parameters. Finally, all results are visually more pleasing than the result of the Wiener filter which contains much ringing. However, the Wiener filter does provide the best MSE. div.head: VI. CONCLUSION
div.p: There are two main contributions in this paper. First, the mean field theory is applied in the EM algorithm for blind image restoration where the original image is modeled by a coupled MRF. As a byproduct, a scheme for deriving mean field equations for line fields with more complex clique structures is developed. Second, the ideas for blur decomposition-compression and the blur smoothness constraint are studied for reducing the number of blur parameters to be estimated and for regularizing the blur parameter estimation process. The experimental results show that the parameter estimates are quite good, and the restoration results are comparable to that of Jeng and Woods [5], which is an effective technique when the image degradation model is known.

An important problem for future work is the estimation of the CGM parameters of the original image along with the blur parameters [29]. Another problem is that the computation time for the EM procedures is still too long for real-time processing or interactive restoration on a workstation or a multiuser computer such as the Convex.
